meta.content: Due to the large volume variation of high-capacity alloy-based anodes during cycling, it is desirable to use small anode particles for an extended battery cycle life. However, it is still challenging to realize subnano-sized particles (<1 nm). Here we show a growth inhibition mechanism that prevents continuous enlargement of size immediately after nucleation during chemical vapour deposition. The growth inhibition is successfully applied to the synthesis of silicon, thereby yielding subnano-sized (<1 nm) silicon embedded in a highly stable dual matrix composed of carbon and silicon carbide. Ethylene not only functions as a silicon growth inhibitor, thereby slowing the growth of nucleated silicon via Si–C bond formation, but also acts as a source to create the dual matrix. The subnano-sized silicon anode enhances the cycling stability (Coulombic efficiency reaching 99.96% over 50 cycles). Finally, the practical application of the fabricated energy storage system (103.2 kWh) containing 110 Ah full-cells with 91% capacity retention for 2,875 cycles and a calendar life of 97.6% for 1 year is demonstrated. Silicon-based anodes are a promising alternative to the graphite anodes that are widely used in today’s commercial batteries. Here the authors report a synthesis route for silicon anodes consisting of subnanometre-sized particles and demonstrate their use in an unusual large-scale battery pack system.

meta.content: Subnano-sized silicon anode via crystal growth inhibition mechanism and its application in a prototype battery pack - Nature Energy

Silicon-based anodes are a promising alternative to the graphite anodes that are widely used in today’s commercial batteries. Here the authors report a synthesis route for silicon anodes consisting of subnanometre-sized particles and demonstrate their use in an unusual large-scale battery pack system.

div.p: Due to the large volume variation of high-capacity alloy-based anodes during cycling, it is desirable to use small anode particles for an extended battery cycle life. However, it is still challenging to realize subnano-sized particles (<1 nm). Here we show a growth inhibition mechanism that prevents continuous enlargement of size immediately after nucleation during chemical vapour deposition. The growth inhibition is successfully applied to the synthesis of silicon, thereby yielding subnano-sized (<1 nm) silicon embedded in a highly stable dual matrix composed of carbon and silicon carbide. Ethylene not only functions as a silicon growth inhibitor, thereby slowing the growth of nucleated silicon via Si–C bond formation, but also acts as a source to create the dual matrix. The subnano-sized silicon anode enhances the cycling stability (Coulombic efficiency reaching 99.96% over 50 cycles). Finally, the practical application of the fabricated energy storage system (103.2 kWh) containing 110 Ah full-cells with 91% capacity retention for 2,875 cycles and a calendar life of 97.6% for 1 year is demonstrated.

Replacing conventional graphite anodes with high-capacity materials is the most promising way to achieve higher energy density lithium-ion batteries
1
. Silicon (Si), which reacts with lithium via an alloying reaction, has been considered as a feasible candidate because of its high specific capacity (3,592 mAh g
−1
)
2
,
3
,
4
,
5
. However, Si suffers from severe structural degradation and instability of the solid–electrolyte interphase (SEI) caused by substantial volumetric fluctuations during (de)lithiation
6
,
7
. These can not only bring about particle fracture and loss of electrical contact with the electrode system but also mechanically disturb the stable formation of the SEI layer and continuously expose the new surface of the material to the electrolyte.

To mitigate these issues, numerous pioneering works over the past decade have proven that decreasing the feature size to the nanoscale allows Si to tolerate the huge dimensional strains without fragmentation and to provide excellent electrochemical behaviours
8
,
9
,
10
. Furthermore, according to previously reported computational studies, subnano-sized Si (approximately 1 nm) leads to much less strain
11
,
12
,
13
. Nonetheless, previous studies on Si-based anodes have focused on managing morphological properties (nanosheets, nanowires, nanotubes, hollow structures and yolk–shell structures) with sizes over several nanometres
14
,
15
,
16
. To the best of our knowledge, the properties of subnano-sized Si anodes have been reported only through simulation because most preceding synthetic approaches, including alloying metals, reduction of silicon oxide, sol–gel, chemical vapour deposition and mechanical milling methods, have limitations in realizing subnano-sized Si (refs.
17
,
18
,
19
). Other challenges include high surface area, low tapping density and air instability (excessive oxidation) when decreasing the Si size
18
,
20
. The high surface area causes severe side reactions with the electrolyte while consuming confined Li
+
ions. The low tapping density of these materials leads to a sparsely packed electrode, which makes it difficult to achieve robust interparticle electronic and ionic pathways, high mass loading and finally high volumetric energy. In addition, Si inevitably has a native oxidation layer (SiO
2
) with a thickness of 2–3 nm in an air atmosphere, but it is negligible for micrometre-sized Si (refs.
21
,
22
). However, for subnano-sized Si, native oxides of even a few nanometres could occupy a considerably large portion of the total weight, resulting in lowering the specific capacity, hindering ionic and electronic conductivity and inducing an irreversible phase.

To address these concerns, incorporation of Si into a composite with other elements has been considered as a rational strategy for small-sized Si. Various carbonaceous materials, including graphite, graphene and amorphous carbon, have been adopted as a buffer matrix for Si composites to alleviate volume changes, block direct exposure of the Si surface to the electrolyte and provide electrically conductive channels
23
,
24
,
25
,
26
,
27
,
28
,
29
. However, they are not robust enough to withstand severe volume fluctuations and are prone to breakage during long-term cycles
30
,
31
,
32
,
33
. Alternatively, Si suboxide (SiO
x
,
x
≤ 1), consisting of a nano-Si domain embedded in a SiO
2
matrix, demonstrates good comprehensive performance and commercial feasibility because of its tiny Si nanocrystals (4–8 nm) and sturdy oxide matrix covering the Si domains conformally. Notwithstanding these advantages, since the oxygen element of SiO
x
produces fatal irreversible phases such as Li
2
O and Li
4
SiO
4
, the use of SiO
x
over a certain amount induces large irreversible capacity losses
34
,
35
. Hence, SiO
x
has been commercialized only on a limited scale (≤4 wt%). On the basis of these facts, we concluded that gradually downsizing Si would lead to more-enhanced characteristics because of improved damage tolerance. Moreover, introducing a robust and Li-inactive matrix could effectively help to address the formidable issues of subnano-sized Si.

The nucleation of Si continues to grow and generates a Si layer during the thermal decomposition of monosilane gas. Hence, we expected that subnano-sized Si would be generated if its growth was obstructed immediately after the nucleation. Through theoretical simulations, we found a growth inhibition mechanism in which the formation of Si–Si bonds could be prevented by ethylene while forming multiple Si–C bonds (Fig.
1a
), which eventually led to the formation of subnano-sized Si clusters during thermal decomposition. Based on this constructive hypothesis and calculation, we synthesized the subnano-sized Si (<1 nm) embedded in a stable dual matrix of silicon carbide and amorphous carbon (SiC/a-C matrix) in a layer structure (denoted the CSi layer) via chemical vapour deposition by using complex gases (SiH
4
and C
2
H
4
). The CSi layer covered carbonaceous supporting frameworks (controllable high capacity over 1,262 mAh g
−1
and Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 90.0%), which showed excellent cycling stability by preserving its morphological integrity without any cracks or pulverization. Consequently, a battery pack (107 kWh) containing 110 Ah full-cells was fabricated to verify the practical application of this anode, which demonstrated cycling stability (91% for 2,875 cycles) and a good calendar life (97.6% for 365 days).

section.data-title: Computational study of Si growth inhibition mechanism

div.h2: Computational study of Si growth inhibition mechanism

div.p:
To verify the hypothesis regarding the role of ethylene as a Si growth inhibitor, the thermal decomposition pathway of the gas mixture (monosilane and ethylene) was computationally studied via density functional theory (DFT) calculations (details in
Methods
, Supplementary Note
1
, Supplementary Figs.
1
and
2
and Supplementary Table
1
). We found that the SiH
3
radical that comes from the decomposition of SiH
4
preferably reacts with ethylene rather than with monosilane. Consequently, the existence of ethylene interrupts the continuous growth of nucleated Si through the formation of the Si–C bond, which results in the formation of subnano-sized Si enclosed in SiC/a-C matrices, unlike the case of the monosilane decomposition without ethylene (Fig.
1b,c
). To theoretically validate the Si growth dynamics during thermal decomposition, we performed reactive molecular dynamics (reax-MD) simulations (details in
Methods
, Supplementary Note
1
, Supplementary Figs.
3
and
4
and Supplementary Table
2
). The ratios of SiH
4
to C
2
H
4
were 10:0, 10:1.5 and 10:5, and were denoted as Si, C(1.5)Si and C(5)Si, respectively. As the ratio of ethylene to monosilane increased from pristine Si to C(5)Si, the growth rate of the atom cluster decreased substantially (Fig.
2a,b
and Supplementary Figs.
5
and
6
), resulting in the smallest particle in the C(5)Si system in terms of the number of Si atoms (Fig.
2c
). Furthermore, the number of Si–Si bonds greatly decreased as ethylene increased, whereas the number of Si–C bonds increased (Fig.
2d,e
). This is because carbon atoms adsorbed at the surface of Si atoms prevent the continuous formation of Si–Si bonds. These atoms therefore suppress the growth of Si clusters, finally leading to the formation of subnano-sized Si and the SiC/a-C matrices. From the above comprehensive results, we conclude that Si growth can be efficiently managed using ethylene acting as a growth inhibitor during the thermal decomposition of the precursor gas.

section.data-title: Tuning Si crystallite size through the growth inhibitor

div.h2: Tuning Si crystallite size through the growth inhibitor

div.p:
We investigated the effects of the Si growth inhibitor on the Si crystallite size by tuning the ratio of the growth inhibitor from pristine Si to a C(7)Si layer. To identify the crystallographic behaviour of Si in the growth-inhibited CSi layer, X-ray diffraction analysis was performed after crystallization through a heat treatment (Supplementary Note
4
and Supplementary Figs.
10
–
13
demonstrating the characteristics of Si and the CSi layer before annealing). In addition, we applied the CSi layer on the amorphous carbon substrate, rather than graphite, to avoid the dilution of the Si-related peaks by the graphitic carbon peaks with relatively high intensity. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the CSi layer coated on graphite is presented in Supplementary Fig.
14
. In Fig.
4a
, the pristine Si layer shows highly intense and sharp peaks assigned to crystallite Si without any trace of the SiC pattern. By contrast, the CSi layer provided very weak and broad Si and SiC peaks compared to those of the pristine Si layer. Note that the Si peak intensities and their full width at half maximum decrease with an increase in the ratio of crystal growth inhibitor. These X-ray diffraction patterns indicated the limit of crystallization of Si by the introduction of the growth inhibitor, and its crystallite size became finer as the growth inhibitor content increased. In addition, the X-ray diffraction results revealed that the emergence of the SiC phase was derived from the growth inhibition mechanism, which acted as an inactive buffer matrix for Si without the formation of irreversible Li compounds. To investigate further, we applied the Scherrer equation to calculate the crystallite size of Si in each sample (Fig.
4b
). To remove aberrations coming from instrumental broadening during measurement of X-ray diffraction
36
,
37
, the Si standard material peak (111) was used to calculate crystallite size (Supplementary Fig.
15
). The size of the Si crystal in the pristine Si layer is about 40 nm, but the CSi layer had a highly reduced crystallite size from 3.8 nm to 0.87 nm due to the hindering of the crystal growth. Notably, the C(5)Si layer has subnano-sized Si of approximately 0.96 nm, and these subnano-sized Si crystals, because of their structural reversibility, are greatly advantageous for repeated (de)alloying with Li ions.

It is well known that crystallite Si (c-Si) undergoes amorphization during electrochemical lithiation while forming the Li
x
Si phase (a-Li
x
Si). However, when the content of lithium in a-Li
x
Si reaches a critical value (
x
= 3.75), a-Li
x
Si is converted to the crystallite Li
15
Si
4
phase (c-Li
15
Si
4
), which gradually grows at potentials lower than 50 mV (ref.
38
). This recrystallization phenomenon causes additional internal stresses associated with phase transition and growth. Eventually, recrystallization leads to particle fracture, which is detrimental to cycling, and is particularly reactive to the electrolyte and the parasitic reaction that removes active Li ions. For these reasons, suppressing c-Li
15
Si
4
is considered an important criterion for determining its performance.

Interestingly, in Fig.
5a
, the voltage plateau at approximately 450 mV, which corresponds to the phase transition of c-Li
15
Si
4
, is notably diminished by the introduction of the crystal growth inhibitor. The pristine Si layer on graphite (pSi-G) clearly had a characteristic peak at 450 mV, but the C(1.5)Si layer on graphite (C(1.5)Si-G) showed a highly reduced peak in the same region. Then, upon testing C(5)Si-G, the characteristic peak vanished. This phenomenon originated from both the effect of subnano-sized Si and robust SiC/a-C dual matrices, which can effectively suppress the evolution of the unfavourable c-Li
15
Si
4
phase by the matrix-induced external force. More interestingly, even with excessive (approximately three times) coating of pSi and C(5)Si layers on the graphite—denoted as E-pSi-G and E-C(5)Si-G—and more excessive (approximately seven times) coating of the CSi layer on the carbon (denoted ME-C(5)Si-C; its SEM images are shown in Supplementary Fig.
17
), the recrystallization phenomenon was still completely suppressed. On the other hand, a much larger characteristic peak for c-Li
15
Si
4
was observed in E-pSi-G than that of pSi-G (Fig.
5b
and Supplementary Fig.
18
). These results indicate that the subnanometre size of Si is maintained and the dual matrix still works well in the C(5)Si regardless of the coating amount (Fig.
5c
). Figure
5d
shows that as the Si content increased, the size of the Si crystal also increased with crystal coarsening, and the Si coating thickness increased. However, the subnano-sized Si crystals in the C(5)Si layer were retained regardless of their coating thickness (Supplementary Fig.
19
shows X-ray diffraction analysis of E-pSi-G and E-C(5)Si-G, and the measurement of coating thickness was based on the magnified cross-sectional SEM images in Supplementary Fig.
20
). These results indicate that it is possible to increase the Si amount without any side effects of the growth of Si size, which has been a severe limitation for high specific capacity via a chemical vapour deposition process
19
. More surprisingly, these subnano-sized Si crystals and the dual matrix do not have an adverse effect on the initial CE (E-C(5)Si-G (92.8%) and E-pSi-G (93.1%) have similar values). This is because SiC/a-C dual matrices have intrinsically high reversibility, unlike the SiO
x
anode accompanying the irreversible phase formation. Furthermore, when specific capacities of each the pSi and CSi layer are calculated and plotted, shown in Fig.
5e
(Supplementary Note
5
, Supplementary Figs.
21
and
22
and Supplementary Table
4
), the specific capacity of the C(5)Si layer is similar regardless of the thickness of the C(5)Si layers in C(5)Si-G, E-C(5)Si-G and ME-C(5)Si-C. The specific capacity and weight ratio of each component in the anodes is shown in Supplementary Fig.
23
.

In the cycling test, we observed that the CE of all samples of pSi-G, C(1.5)Si-G and C(5)Si-G increased to 99.5% after four or five cycles, which is similar to our previously reported Si–graphite hybrids
19
. However, the CE of C(5)Si-G reached 99.96% at the 50th cycle, whereas the CE was 99.72% and 99.78% for pSi-G and C(1.5)Si-G, respectively (Fig.
5f
). Considering that the average CE reaching at least 99.96% is imperative for a capacity retention ratio of over 80% during 500 cycles (calculation in Supplementary Fig.
24
), these results indicate that C(5)Si-G is qualified for long-term cycling performance.

To substantiate the superiority of the C(5)Si, we investigated the differential capacity (d
Q
/d
V
) plots characterizing the delithiation of ME-C(1.5)Si-C and ME-C(5)Si-C during cycling (Fig.
5h
). A voltage plateau of approximately 450 mV (phase transition of c-Li
15
Si
4
) continues to emerge after the first cycle in the case of ME-C(1.5)Si-C, implying that the Si size continues to increase through the coalescence of lithiated Si with adjacent Si upon cycling. By contrast, ME-C(5)Si-C has no characteristic peak at 450 mV, which means that the subnano-sized Si, with a size of less than 1 nm, retains its morphological integrity while inhibiting the coalescence of Si upon repeated lithiation and delithiation processes. These results provided a reason why realizing the subnano-sized Si is imperative for stable high-capacity Si anodes with long-term cycling stability.

div.h2: Full-cell evaluation and post-cycling analysis of the CSi layer

). By contrast, the capacity retention of pSi-G was 57.6% (voltage profile is shown in Supplementary Fig.
26b
, and the cell design and electrochemical estimation (an areal capacity of >3.3 mAh cm
–2
) are given in Supplementary Table
5
and Supplementary Fig.

, respectively).

In addition, we evaluated other critical requirements for practical use, such as the cycling stability and electrode volume expansion at a high temperature (45 °C), at which the electrode degradation is accelerated (Supplementary Fig.
29
). Even at a high temperature (45 °C), C(5)Si-G provided a superior capacity retention ratio (82.3%) over 200 cycles and a low electrode expansion of less than 35% during cycling. C(5)Si-G also demonstrated an outstanding rate capability of 79.6% capacity retention at 5 C (Supplementary Fig.
30
for voltage profile at a different current of discharge).

A post-cycling analysis of the 1 Ah stacking cell was conducted to investigate the advantageous effect of subnano-sized Si with SiC/a-C dual matrices for long-term cycling. Supplementary Fig.
31
shows the cross-sectional SEM images of pSi-G and C(5)Si-G before cycling. Both pSi-G and C(5)Si-G exhibited a well-attached coating layer on the graphite. However, after 500 cycles, pSi-G showed a highly degraded and detached from the graphite Si layer (Fig.
6b,d
). When Si degradation revealed the newly exposed surface during cycling, it not only continuously consumed the limited electrolyte and Li ions, but also increased the internal resistance of the cell by electrical contact loss and a thickened SEI layer. Because practical batteries use only highly limited electrolytes and Li sources, such degradation would severely limit the long-term cycle life. By contrast, the C(5)Si-G electrode sustains its morphological integrity, and the C(5)Si layer is well attached to the graphite (Fig.
6c,e
; Supplementary Fig.
32
shows a photograph of the cycled electrode).

To clarify the preservation of the morphology of the C(5)Si layer, the crystallite structure of SiC was investigated using a ME-C(5)Si-C electrode during cycling. In this analysis, the reason we selected ME-C(5)Si-C is that both the amorphous phase of carbon and excessive SiC amount offer the advantage of detecting crystallite SiC. We observed that a clear peak assigned to SiC existed even after 500 cycles (half-cell) through the X-ray diffraction and TEM analyses (Fig.
6f,g
), indicating that SiC with a high mechanical strength could act as a robust matrix to a Si volume change. A cross-sectional SEM image and magnified TEM images of ME-C(5)Si-C after 100 cycles are also shown in Supplementary Fig.
33
. The C(5)Si layer does not show crack propagation at either the micro- or nanoscale, which means that there is no pathway or pores for the electrolyte to open up a crack and penetrate into the C(5)Si layer. We believe that the highly mitigated stress evolution originating from the decreased size of Si to the subnanometre level, along with the crystalltee SiC and a-C matrices, preserves its morphological integrity and results in stable SEI layer formation without electrolyte penetration into the CSi layer (Fig.
6h
for a schematic of the charge and discharge mechanisms of the pSi and CSi layer).

Beyond the small-sized stacked cell evaluation, performance verification in a practical-scale cell configuration is essential, particularly with the adoption of Si-based anodes, because the electrolyte depletion and safety issues caused by Si expansion become more severe in large-capacity cells. We fabricated a prismatic-type winding cell with a capacity above 110 Ah by using graphite-blended C(5)Si-G (C(5)Si-G/Gra) and a LiNi
0.8
Co
0.1
Mn
0.1
O
2
(NCM811) cathode; Supplementary Fig.
34
shows the voltage profile and cycle stability with patterned cycling conditions. C(5)Si-G/Gra provided a surprisingly stable cycle lifespan (91.3%) for 2,875 cycles without any cell deformation (Fig.
7a
). We also measured the in-situ cell thickness change of the C(5)Si-G/Gra during cycles in a 1 Ah pouch-type cell, as shown in the inset of Fig.
7a
. The C(5)Si-G/Gra showed very low volume expansion (13.8%) at the first cycle, as well as a stabilized cell thickness change for repeated cycles. These low and stable cell volume changes can avoid cell deformation and achieve stable electrochemical behaviour in densely packed prismatic cell designs.

To further confirm the safety of the 110 Ah prismatic-type cell, we conducted assorted safety testing such as external short circuit, thermal stability and overcharging (Fig.
7b–d
; the detailed evaluation conditions are in the
Methods
), and these cells did not catch fire or burst. Because such a safe and prominent electrochemical performance gives us the promise of practical application, by using these prismatic cells, we assembled a 8.6 kWh class battery module composed of 22 prismatic cells and then a 103.2 kWh prototype battery pack consisting of 12 battery modules as shown in Fig.
7e
(detailed electrode composition and specifications in Supplementary Tables
6
and
7
). Because this type of battery pack is a practically used model for energy storage systems, we used it to set up an energy storage system (Supplementary Fig.
35
). When it operated in the voltage range between approximately 943 and 962 V, it exhibited an energy of 10.5 kWh without capacity fading or drastic temperature change (Fig.
7f
and Supplementary Fig.
36
). We also conducted a cell storage test—with details provided in the
Methods
—to measure the battery’s calendar life (Fig.
7g
). In this test, we traced the battery’s recovery capacity for a full year and found a 97.6% recovery capacity after 365 days.

We synthesized subnano-sized Si anodes using ethylene as a particle growth inhibitor in a thermal decomposition process of silane. In contrast to the decomposition of pure silane, where the Si particles continue to increase in size, ethylene reacts with silane, forming Si–C bonds, thereby maintaining the subnano-sized particles even when an excessive coating is present on the carbonaceous substrate. Moreover, forming Si–C bonds contributes to generating the robust matrix of crystallite SiC, which not only prevents the formation of a native SiO
2
layer but also helps to preserve the morphological integrity of the C(5)Si layer during long-term cycling. Thus, C(5)Si-G demonstrates a high initial CE and cycling stability when estimated using a practically feasible testing protocol. The fabricated energy storage system (107 kWh) consisting of 110 Ah full-cells containing subnano-sized Si anodes showed cycling stability (91% for 2,875 cycles) and a good calendar life (97.6% for 365 days). These results can provide inspiration for battery researchers to consider the parameters for high-capacity alloy anode design and can pave the way for next-generation anodes in high-energy lithium-ion battery systems for application in energy storage systems and electric vehicles.

The Si layer was coated on the substrate (commercial spherical-type natural graphite and carbon nanoparticle) in a customized stainless steel tube furnace via thermal decomposition of high-purity monosilane gas (99.9999%) at 475 °C at a flow rate of 0.05 l min
‒1
for 35 and 60 min (denoted Si-G and E-Si-G respectively) using a graphite substrate. For the fabrication of the C(5)Si layer, high-purity monosilane and ethylene (99.9%) were streamed at 475 °C at a flow rate of 0.05 l min
‒1
at a volume ratio of 10:5 for 45 min (denoted C(5)Si-G), 78 min (denoted E-C(5)Si-G) and 165 min (denoted ME-C(5)Si-C, where C is the amorphous carbon nanoparticle substrate (Super P, TIMCAL)), and at 10:1.5 for 40 min (denoted C(1.5)Si-G). All samples were coated by 5 wt% pitch-based carbon (10 wt% carbon coat for the ME-C(5)Si-C anode) and annealed at 900 °C in the case of electrochemical characterization. As the total purity of the gas mixture of monosilane and ethylene was not as high as 99.9999%, utilization of a highly purified gas mixture is not essential for the synthesis of CSi-G.

Structural investigation of the CSi layer was conducted using SEM (Verios 460, FEI) and high-resolution TEM (JEM-2100F, JEOL) with EDS (Aztec, Oxford). For the TEM analysis, dual-beam focused ion beam milling (Helios 450HP, FEI) with a 2–30 kV Ga ion beam was used for the preparation of samples. Before analysis of the focused ion beam milling, epoxy soaking and carbon deposition were performed to avoid damage from the Ga ion beam and maintain the sample morphology in the process of lift-out and thinning. The thinned samples with a thickness of 200 nm were next polished to remove surface contamination using an Ar-ion milling system (Model 1040 Nanomill, Fischione) and immediately transferred to the TEM instrument. The chemical states of each layer were analysed by EELS and XPS (K-alpha, ThermoFisher). EELS data were calibrated against the π* peak of the K edge of amorphous carbon, which is accurately locked at 285 eV. For the calibration of the binding energy of the XPS spectra, we used the adventitious carbon 1
s
peak of 284.5 eV as the internal standard. An X-ray diffractometer (D/MAZX 2500V/PC, Rigaku, with Cu Kα of wavelength 1.542 Å) and Raman spectroscopy (NRS-5000, JASCO) were used for the physicochemical characterization. The elemental composition of C(5)Si-G was analysed by element analyser (Flash 2000, Thermo). To examine the morphological change of electrodes and samples after 500 cycles, the cycled pouch-type cells were disassembled in an Ar-filled glove box (H
2
O < 1 ppm, O
2
< 1 ppm), and electrodes were rinsed with excess dimethyl carbonate. Then, the electrode was cut by an ion milling system (IM-40000, Hitachi) for analysis of cross-sectional SEM images and cut by focused ion beam milling (above-mentioned procedures) for analysis of cross-sectional TEM images. The ionic conductivity of the electrolyte was measured by a conductivity meter (Eutech CON 150, ThermoFisher). The cyclic voltammetry curve was measured by a Wonatech WBCS3000 at a scan rate of 0.5 mV s
−1
.

The thickness change of the 1 Ah pouch-type full-cell (C(5)Si-G/LCO and pSi-G/LCO; LCO, lithium cobalt oxide) after 20 cycles was estimated by an electrochemical dilatometer (Mitutoyo). Electrochemical conditions were the same as those in the electrochemical characterization of the full-cell except for temperature (45 °C). In the case of the 1 Ah pouch-type full-cell (C(5)Si-G/Gra/NCM811), the measurement of electrode thickness changes was performed after a degassing process.

The electrode was fabricated using the active material (Si-G, E-Si-G, C(1.5)Si-G, C(5)Si-G and E-C(5)Si-G), the carbon black (Super P, TIMCAL), carboxymethyl cellulose (Nippon paper) and styrene–butadiene rubber (Zeon) at the mass ratio of 96:1:1.5:1.5. The slurry was cast on copper foil up to 5.35 mg cm
−2
(Si-G, C(1.5)Si-G and C(5)Si-G) and 3.3 mg cm
−2
(E-Si-G and E-C(5)Si-G). All electrodes were then dried at 110 °C for 6 h in the vacuum oven and calendered to increase the electrode density to 1.6 g cm
−3
. A CR2032 coin-type half-cell was assembled by sandwiching the microporous polyethylene (20 μm, Celgard) between the electrodes and lithium metal foil (>99%, Honjo Metal) in the Ar-filled glove box. Then 1.3 M LiPF
6
in a mixture of ethylene carbonate, ethyl methyl carbonate and diethyl carbonate (3:5:2, v/v) with 10% fluoroethylene carbonate, 0.2% lithium tetrafluoroborate (LiBF
4
), 0.5% vinylene carbonate, 3% succinonitrile and 1% propane sultone (Panax Starlyte) was used as the electrolyte. The electrochemical assessment was carried out in a voltage range of 0.005 V (cut-off voltage, 0.01 V) to 1.5 V at a rate of 0.1 C for the first cycle, and 0.005 V (constant voltage mode for charging, where the cut-off voltage was 0.01 C) to 1.0 V at a rate of 0.5 C for the rest of the cycles. All cells were charged at constant current and CV mode for subsequent cycles. The LCO electrode was fabricated by mixing LCO powder, Super P and polyvinylidene fluoride binder with a mass ratio of 96:2:2 on the aluminium foil. The mass loading level and electrode density of the LCO were 15.5 mg cm
−2
and 3.5 g cm
−3
, respectively. The separator, electrolyte and battery cycler were used in the same way as in the above anode tests. The electrochemical evaluations were assessed in a voltage range between 3 and 4.2 V at a rate of 0.1 C at the first cycle and 0.5 C for the rest of the cycles. Electrochemical analysis of all coin-type half-cells was conducted using a battery cycler (TOSCAT-3100, TOYO SYSTEM) at 25 °C.

The electrode was punched into rectangular pieces with a size of 72.5 mm × 55.0 mm (cathodes) and 75.5 mm × 58.0 mm (anodes) for the pouch-type full-cells with >1,000 mAh. The pouch-cell assembly was conducted with stacking of the cathode, anode and separator at ~7–8 layer construction; ultrasonic welding for connection of the electrode with Al (cathode) and Ni (anode) external tabs; and vacuum sealing with electrolyte injection in a dry room (relative humidity, 0.05%; 20 °C). The electrode composition of the cathode or anode, separator and electrolyte was the same as those of half-cells except that a slurry was coated on both sides of a current collector such as copper and aluminium. Both the areal capacity ratio of negative to positive electrode and ratio of electrolyte weight to cell capacity are <1.1 and <2 g Ah
−1
, respectively, with the limited Li source and electrolyte, to correspond to the values used in conventional lithium-ion batteries. The electrochemical evaluations were assessed in a voltage range between 2.5 and 4.2 V at a rate of 0.1 C at the first cycle and 0.2 C for three cycles (ageing and degassing processes were conducted at the first cycle). For the rest of the cycles, cells were charged and discharged in a voltage range between 2.85 and 4.2 V at a rate of 0.5 C. Electrochemical analysis of all pouch-type full-cells was carried out using a battery cycler (PECC05-06, PNE SOLUTION) at 25 and 45 °C. For the case of the 110 Ah prismatic-type full-cell, the electrode was fabricated using an anode (C(5)Si-G/Gra; loading level, 7.5 mg cm
−2
) and cathode (NCM811; loading level, 13.4 mg cm
−2
), and the electrode composition was the same as with the C(5)Si-G electrode. The pressure of the 1 Ah pouch-type full-cell and 110 Ah prismatic-type full-cell was 5 and 10 psi, respectively. All electrochemical tests in this study were conducted in isothermal chambers with a constant temperature. In the case of the pack-scale system for energy storage systems, the system also had an active cooling fan to avoid the overheating of the system. The electrochemical evaluations (cycle test) were assessed under a patterned cycle condition used for practical energy storage system operation. In the testing of the calerdar life, the cell was stored in a state of charge of 25% at 30 °C. The phenomena of knee-type drop-off and the electrolyte drying out were not considered when expecting the calendar life using the trend curve. The fabrication was suppoorted by Samsung SDI, and the other evaluation conditions and fabrication processes are confidential.
div.h3: Safety testing of 110 Ah prismatic full-cell
div.p:
For the external short-circuit test, the cell was fully charged with a state of charge of 100% and then rested for 12 h. Then, an external short circuit was conducted by connecting the anode and cathode at an external resistance of approximately 30 mΩ for 6 h. For the thermal test, a fully charged cell was heated to 85 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min
−1
and held there for 3 h. For the overcharging test, after reaching a fully discharged state (depth of discharge, 100%), the cell rests for 1 h; then, we started to charge the cell at 0.33 C until a cut-off voltage was reached of 5.22 V (overcharging to 120% of the initial voltage).

All reax-MD simulations were conducted with the reactive forcefield (reaxFF) developed by Soria et al.
42
and implemented in the Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator (LAMMPS) package
43
,
44
. Reax-MD simulations were carried out in a two-step approach: formation of a Si cluster from precursor gases (Supplementary Fig.
3a
) and formation of a CSi layer from the nucleated Si clusters (Supplementary Fig.
3b
). To mimic the experimental environment, we modelled a graphene-mixture gas (SiH
4
and C
2
H
4
) interfacial system (‘Initial system I’ in Supplementary Fig.
3a
), which consisted of three layers of graphene and a mixture of monosilane and ethylene with a density of 0.05 g cm
–3
. In this study, three ratios of monosilane and ethylene were considered (that is, 10:0, 10:1.5 and 10:5, denoted Si, C(1.5)Si and C(5)Si, respectively), and the number of monosilane molecules was fixed at 159 (Supplementary Table
2
). The interfacial model systems were relaxed through a
NVT
(that is,
N
,
V
and
T
are the total number of atoms, volume and temperature at each simulation condition) reax-MD simulation at room temperature for 100 ps with a time step of 0.1 fs. After that, the simulation temperature was elevated to the reaction temperature (that is, 1,800 K) at a heating rate of 250 K ps
−1
. Thermal decomposition reactions of the heated model systems were then propagated through
NVT
reax-MD simulation for 1 ns. Pressurized conditions of the mixture gas precursors and elevated reaction temperature (that is, 0.5 g cm
−3
and 1,800 K) were chosen to allow the decomposition reactions of the mixture gas to be completed in a practical simulation time. Similar approaches have been applied in several previous studies observing reactions of SiC (refs.
45
,
46
).

To observe the structure of the CSi layer with and without ethylene gas, Si clusters grown in the Si and C(1.5)Si systems were taken from the last configuration of reax-MD. Ten copies of the Si clusters were randomly packed in an empty simulation box with a packing density of 0.5 g cm
−3
(‘Initial system II’ in Supplementary Fig.
3b
). Note that two small Si clusters were made from the complex gas system, so ten copies of each cluster (a total of 20 clusters) were packed in the Initial system II of the C(1.5)Si system. Modelled systems were quenched from the simulation temperature (1,800 K) to the experimental reaction temperature (900 K) with a cooling rate of 250 K ps
−1
, and a further
NPT
(isothermal and isobaric.
P
is the pressure of the simulation system) reax-MD simulation was conducted at 50 atm for 200 ps.
